commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Crack expert?  (5)
2. Rock, for one  (5)
3. Deep study  (10)
4. Check-in line?  (3)(3)(4)
5. Part of Wayne's world?  (7)


COMIC
COMIC
OCEANOLOGY
ARE YOU GOOD
WESTERN
The "ayes" have it!  Very cute puzzle. I loved it!
I don't think history will repeat this time :)

Corollary to the revealer's [Coaching axiom]:
   ...but there is in WIN.
Great Monday puzzle! Elegant and fun, with a cozy theme reveal

Sam, hope you read about the Rosetta Stone because it’s a fascinating story; if you are in London go see it at the British Museum. I’m always fascinated at some of the things otherwise well educated and intelligent people (this includes myself) have gaps about in their knowledge.
I thought this was very clever and well constructed for a Monday.
That was cute and elegant. Great puzzle!

Good thing that Oyster didn't fit for type of cracker served with chowder.

I enjoyed solving this bright and lively Monday puzzle. 

Thanks guys.
Leon's take on there being an "i" in team: https://tinyurl.com/2czenwsa
So quick and fun! Go Giants!

Possible POY for Monday, what an engaging puzzle!

I'm afraid (and I think fellow Pittsburghers Josh, Sue, Al, et al. will agree) that there's not much of a team left to cheer on here, and no coaching bromide will help us through this: we have a skinflint owner, and there's only one way that ends -- at the bottom of the standings. SELL THE TEAM, BOB!

Can never remember whether it's Eastern Daylight Time or Eastern Standard Time. Dang it!
This was such fun! I loved the theme. Go, Yankees! Thanks!
Played this while the MARNERS played another fantastic ball game. Go M’s!

Nice Monday puzzle, with a solid and cute theme and some interesting fill: PEGASUS, SALTINE, ROSETTA, OILPASTELS, ONIONBAGEL.

Took me about 7.5 minutes, which for me is faster than usual for a Monday.

I beg your humble pardon, but one eats oyster crackers with chowder, not saltines. Because the word chowder refers, for ever and ever, to New England clam chowder and no other. 

Otherwise,  it waa a lovely, quick puzzle.
Didn't look to see what the theme was but finished in record time.
Didn’t figure out the theme until I got to cameo roles and then was trying to do cameorioles and realized what was going on. Enjoyed this very much. 3:44 under my Monday average

Mathematician here! I always love seeing math related clues, and loved the rest of the puzzle. I do have a small nitpick: mathematically, something can be [One dimensional] but not LINEAR! (and vice versa). As an example, almost all curves are one dimensional but not linear!
Fun and breezy! I guessed the theme from the SF answer, and it helped me fill in the other two.

There is no u in chocolate.

Good puzzle!

Fun fact: ETCH and ENGRAVE are two different intaglio processes in printing. Engravings are like portraits on US paper money, where lines are tooled or carved out of the metal plate. Etchings are made by painting corrosive chemicals on metal to wear away the design. Not synonymous, if you’re considering the last 500 of printing, but no biggie!
Eli means "ascent", not "high". This is, of course, when it isn't a diminutive for a theophoric name, as it often is.
Pretty hilarious.
An "I" was about the only thing the Giants did not lack today against the Dodgers.

A great day at the ballpark is pitcher-perfect.

(But inning isn't everything.)

🤪🤣

I am rarely as confused by Thursday themes as I was by today's, on a Monday - at least before I got to the revealer, which made me understand both what was going on and why I was so clueless before.

Thankfully the fill was truly Monday easy. Otherwise I would have struggled terribly with a puzzle such as this.

It's a bit meh that the themed phrases have no  deeper connection to the cities or teams (because they don't, right?) - it makes the theme feel a bit random.

ARENA is a word in Polish, too, but we don't use it to describe any huge venue. It only appears in commercial names of a few venues (like the Atlas Arena in the city of Łódź - Atlas is a sponsor), I suppose under English influence. The Polish arena has a much narrower meaning than the English one: in its literal sense it only means the center stage of a circus, ancient amphitheater or corrida stadium. We would never call the center of a sport stadium or the whole stadium an arena. Neither would we use the word for a concert hall or some such. In a symbolic sense, as in English, it may mean an activity or place of competition or discussion, as in political arena (arena polityczna).

There’s no I in Team, but there is in Win 😆

Catch ya later! ⚾️

A busy weekend so catching up with a Super Saturday, a Silly Sunday and a Marvy Monday (it is actually charming but there's no M in that). 

Played around with the name of our local squad but the double L defeated me.  Best I could come up with was too self referential: 

[Orientation for the new airport employees]

PHLLESSONS

Oh well.
And here I thought the NYT Crossword was a safe space for my socially-debilitating lack of sportball knowledge, but alas.
GenAI is put so gently when it's detrimental to society, the environment, and peoples' minds. Do better.

I really love today’s crossword!! Even though I know nothing about sports, baseball and English is my second language ( im fluid in English) I finally got a crossword where I really could dive into it. Most of the answers I could figure out myself, EVEN THE BASEBALL ONES!! And I loved it!! Loved finally doing a crossword for real and not having to search for hints on 80% of it and stumble on things I have never heard of, even though I’m perfectly fluid in English. 

I think crosswords like this really help spreading the NYT games to a broader international audience.

Loved the puzzle today! Cute theme. 

However:
The Hebrew name ELI (אלי) means “my God.”  
No Israeli would think otherwise. It is spelled with an aleph (א).

“High” as a clue perhaps confuses it with עלי/עליון Ali or Alyon (“to ascend,” “Most High”).
Ngenous.

I really liked the nice payoff when I finished this puzzle. Monday is my only ‘speed solve’ day and I frequently miss the point of these puzzles. Today, the revealer sucked me in and each find was a little present. Thanks!
Thank you, Matthew and Michael. Such fun!

TIL flâneur. Thanks, Sam.

Somewhat tricky theme for a Monday, but the fill came in easily enough.


Emus ate my post yesterday. BEEP BEEP.

This was great fun.

And wow! I didn't need to look up anything and inserted American clues like IHOP and EMTS like a pro. I had thought ICEE was an ice cream, though. 

I thought ONION bahji not BAGEL, I can get bahjis everywhere, but never seen the BAGEL. Fortuitously I learnt the mnemonic for rainbow here last week. 

Nice one.

How 'bout this twist to the coaching axiom, 63A: ...but there is a ME. Well, sorta.

Lots of fun with this one! Got the revealer right away, but didn't make the connection to the parenthetical cities until I actually read them through. I have a tendency to jump on an answer after looking at the first word or two.
Clever theme and fun solve, nice start to the week.
A nice light moment, as always on a Monday.  But you still confuse ‘etch’ with ‘engrave’.

I love a good sports theme! I’m with Matthew Stock - Go Cubs! 🐻 ⚾️! Just got to see them last week at Truist Park in ATL, a great place to watch baseball, but it’s no Wrigley Field! And thank you, Sam, for the iconic scene from “A League of Their Own”!

Just got a funny image in my head of emus playing baseball! When, oh when, will Apple give us an emu emoji?

"Ingenious fix" was perfectly acceptable as a crossword clue for "elegant solution," but I'm going to nitpick it a little anyway.

An "elegant" solution isn't just ingenious. It's also simple.

I once, during my career as a baker, approached the head engineer at my facility with my solution for a problem with a piece of machinery. It involved the installation of a plexiglass (I.e "perflex") shield to prevent small pieces of dough from dropping into the machinery of a dough conveyor and slowing the belt,  causing a feedback loop that eventually stopped the conveyor and shut the line down while it was dealt with. I am used to thinking in terms of stuff I can buy off the shelf at, say, Home Depot, so my idea involved a Rube Goldberg construction of threaded rods and multiple parts. 

But our head engineer was a machinist, among his many other talents. He came back with a device that accomplished the same thing, but it consisted of a single aluminum bar with a 45° twist, to which a very specifically shaped piece of 1/4" plexiglass was bolted. 

It accomplished the same thing that my gizmo was trying to do, but it was a far more elegant solution.

I got the theme answers. Then I got the revealer with hardly any letters filled in. So I understood the fun part. What I didn't get until much later was that the cities were the ones that host those particular teams. Duh!

Matthew (32 NYT puzzles) and Michael (31) are top tier constructors, and their skill is evident in this theme.  

First, they had to find three team names that you can remove the letter “I” from, and have what’s left be part of both words of a two-word phrase.  I believe the three they found are the only ones in MLB that work.

Second, those two-word phrases had to fit symmetry in the grid – one had to be a spanner to match the revealer, and the other two had to have the same number of letters.

Wow!  Bravo!  

My brain got its workout at trying to guess the revealer, the highlight being trying to anagram the circled letters and wondering if STANG was a word.  I also liked seeing TOTEM as a vertical answer, as well as the PuzzPair© of HEIST and a backward LOOT.  

Quality puzzle, quality solve.  Even with those i’s in your full name, Michael, you and Matthew make an excellent team.  Thank you both for a most lovely start to the week!

Yep! I think people get confused between the dimensionality of the graphical representation of the curve and the dimensionality of the curve itself. e.g.

y = sin(x) 

This is a 1-d curve, given that there is a single parameter. The y axis on the graph represents output, rather than input.

Whizzed through this without have a clue re theme. Needed a second look at the completed grid to finally understand, because football. 

The diagnosis is in; I have the ‘flu, which I’ve now passed on to DH. And he says I never share. 

The plague cross has been daubed on the front door, though as I’m 10 days in surely it can’t last much longer?😷
What a great start to the week. Baseball fever is ramping up around here. Go Jays!

Mondays are easy for us solvers, but hard for constructors.  How to make it doable for beginners, but interesting for the experienced?

Today's puzzle is about as good as it gets.  Pretty easy (IMHO), but with a theme that slowly reveals itself, until you get that pleasant "A-ha" moment.
And timely as the lo-o-ong baseball season moves into its final month.

Nice job, Matthew Stock and Michael Lieberman!
Go, Yanks!
Nice work, lads. A theme that's so dopey you gotta love it.

Loved this one! As a born-and-raised Maryland girl, as soon as I saw OROLES in 49A, the theme fell together for me. One of my quickest solves yet, and a genuinely fun Monday puzzle - great job to the constructors!
If you feel like you need more of a challenge to start the week, try today’s New Yorker by Anna Shechtman: https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2025/09/15

I loved today's puzzle! I am always fond of an early week puzzle with a theme--I remember when I was a new solver and the Monday/Tuesdays were the only puzzles I could routinely solve without assistance, but I felt rather left out by never having a theme like the Thursday and onward puzzles, so it's always nice to see these. I've enjoyed reading others' comments on the impressive construction of the grid! I especially liked the cross of 25A and 28D, and also 64D.

One thing--does anybody else solving on desktop have a banner at the top of the screen offering a family subscription? It makes it so I cannot see the last row of the grid, and the puzzle jumps when I get to the final clues so that I can't see the top where the clue is written solo, only the side lists. It's a little thing, but it's driving me absolutely bananas. I'd hoped it would go away after a week!

Fun Monday puzzle and a pretty smooth solve. The reveal was almost the last thing I filled in and that just made for a nice 'aha' moment. And... THERESNOIINTEAM was the 'reveal' in a rather amazing Sunday puzzle from June 3, 2018 by David J. Kahn with the title "Proving them wrong." And the clue for that answer was: "Sports axiom refuted by this puzzle" And the theme answers in that one were all crossing answers - across and down. Some examples: detroIt crossing tIgers washIngton crossing natIonals mInnesota crossing twIns stlouIs crossing cardInals All of those pairs crossing each other at the "I" (which I capitalized) Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/3/2018&g=63&d=A ....
Flaneur ISO flaneuse.

I was afraid those were anagrams....'cause I couldn't make heads nor tails out of them!  
Given that these two Constructor names belong to Matthew Stock and Michael Lieberman (whom, if they were in my classroom, I would seat well apart) we are getting off lightly.
Delightful puzzle.  The only truly puzzling part was why someone felt it necessary to put the city names in the clues.  We don't need no stinkin' hints. 
 Or badges.  Baseball Forever!
Delightful Monday puzzle. Thank you!
Lots of fun! Great way to start the week. I even got the theme before I read the Wordplay!

A proper mechanic does not wear a TOOL belt, as doing so dramatically increases the odds of scratching the paint. The rolling TOOL chest is de rigueur.

Fun Monday puzzle, although SILAS MARNER was disappointed not to be included in the theme.
Cute, fun puzzle! Made for a nice start to the week.
Terrific theme idea!
Nice and easy puzzle for a Monday, very creative revealer. Thanks
Very clever theme. Years ago in choir practice the director said I was being too loud and I jokingly said, there actually is an I in choir 🤣
Great way to start the week...a home run, guys!!

i caught myself just in time from posting congrats on having only 2 sports clues (12D and 41D). Doh!
 I guess it's because baseball is the sport I followed as a child and I still know most team names (despite or perhaps because of lingering hard feelings about some of the moves; I rooted for the Dodgers.)
  Interesting commentary on my diminishing eyesight, smallness of phone screen or brain's tendency to fill in the blanks, but when I grasped that there were embedded team names, I didn't notice the missing "I" in the Pittsburgh or Baltimore teams. Only jumped out in the San Francisco one.
While there is no I in team, with a slight movement of letters, there is a ME. Fun solve today for sure.
Oh, Sam, aucune excuse n'est nécessaire, friend. https://xkcd.com/1053/ Congrats on your TIL!

Thank you, Sam!

“I” was blown away!😄
FANTASTIC puzzle today!!
Very clever!

Linear does not mean one dimensional

My first ever sub-4 minute puzzle! This one was a delightful breeze.
Just a trivia (or trivium?):  Hanoi literally means within the (bend of)  the (Red) river, due to the location of the ancient city.

a grand slam Monday debut beautiful puzzle BRAVO!
Great puzzle! It would be a great one to suggest to brand new solvers.
PB Sunday followed by PB Monday. That doesn't happen often. I'll take it.
Fastest I’ve gotten any sort of idea of the theme but took me a bit to get the revealer. Very fun
3:53 today, love getting under 4

5D is not correct. Things that are the answer need not just be one-dimensional. And things that are one-dimensional need not be the answer. The concept of the answer describes the geometry of an object, whereas the concept of one-dimensional describes the size of the space an object occupies.

Personal best of 7:50 today!

Wow, seeing a handful of you under 4 minutes is super impressive
Funny theme but I solved it pretty fast without any of the clue words.

[Found darling]  (6)


RAM
ADORED

I see you've solved the busy morning problem by doing the puzzle the evening before. I'm not sure what I think about that!
(But I do know how much you should care about what I think.)

Kathleen,

You and I and many others eat oyster crackers with chowder. I'm sorry to report that I have, at times, observed the eating of saltines with chowder. The answer is sad but true.

@Kathleen

I don't know, I just think adding crackers made of oyster is too much for a clam chowder.

Maybe a corn chowder... 

I jest, I'm not an eater of clams or oysters, but I did try to put oyster in there first, before surprisingly having to change it to SALTINE. Even this lifelong Midwesterner knew the correct answer should be oyster.  ☺️

HeathieJ,

I'm glad you know. It may not surprise you to learn that many of my SALTINE sightings have been in the Midwest.

@Kathleen
Herman Melville refers also to cod chowder. When Ishmael enters the Spouter Inn on Nantucket the proprietor asks “Clam or Cod” being the only two items on the menu. There is also Bermuda Chowder, which is mixed seafood.

Barry Ancona,

Ha!  Definitely not surprised to hear it. 

There's is a nice restaurant here that we frequent. My husband orders the clam chowder if they have it, and it actually does come with oyster crackers, but he's tried it in a number of other places and typically get saltines. He usually never orders it at those places again.

Last summer we went to Boston and Cape Cod and he got to enjoy the real deal a few times... And I got to enjoy the best lobster roll I've ever had, thanks to @G's recommendation. 

Around here, better to enjoy our delicious walleye, trout, etc. Especially when you can get it with potato pancakes!
No, Francis; just good taste. And good tastes.

@Kathleen
Oh, goody. Yesterday, it was BEEP vs MEEP. Today, it's the chowder wars. (Yawn)

One of the major companies in the Fairfax district in Kansas City, KS, down the street from General Motors, was Sunshine Biscuits, bakers of millions of SALTINES, among other items. It was bought by Keebler in '96, and the site is now a Kelloggs production facility, and still making crackers, but now they're baking Cheez-Its. Always good ODORs near that place.

Nice Monday puzzle, with some interesting words and nice little trick for the theme.

Thanks, guys!

@JayTee
One sad side effect of the estrangement between Our Two Great Nations (tm) is that I will no longer buy Cheez-its. They, along with any brand of cheese puff or cheese twist, are the ideal snack food. They conceal their complete of nutritional value behind  the thinnest of veils -- a smidgen of cheese. My local supermarket keeps offering special sales on Cheez-its (along with Oreos, etc.) but my elbows remain resolutely up!

@Francis

I wonder if my comment that I tried to post twice will show up tomorrow. We shall see.... ☺️

@SBK
Our friends in Windsor insist that they cannot purchase oyster crackers in Canada. I find this hard to be true, but they ask us to smuggle them over the border for them, along with Pepperidge Farms frozen coconut cakes, and those organic multi-grain tortilla chips from Aldi's.
OTOH, we generally have a couple of Dr. Oetker's pizzas in our freezer.
The underground economy continues.

(BTW, we've started keeping  a "go-bag" handy.)

@Kathleen

Please explain the difference between the two crackers to us cretins.
Lenny, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oyster_cracker https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saltine_cracker

@Bill
I'm not a chowder fan, so I will note that Skyline Chili comes with a packet of oyster crackers. I imagine that chowder is salty enough on its own.

@Francis
Not any different than being caught putting ketchup on a freshly grilled Angus steak.

@Barry Ancona

That's nice but the dictionary doesn't do a comparison.

@SBK

As one who spends two weeks in BC each fall, I eagerly anticipate the opportunity to buy and consume Hawkins "Cheezies", a much superior Canadian version of the American "Cheetos", and a great accompaniment to a Caesar cocktail. Cheezies have more than a smidgeon of cheddar powder, and a vastly more satisfying crunch. Surely one who has an appreciation of the ideal snack food must have sampled these divine nuggets!
@Pedro aren't lines 2d? A point is 1d.
@John A point is dimensionless. You need two points to talk about dimensions.

@Pedro Yep! I think people get confused between the dimensionality of the graphical representation of the curve and the dimensionality of the curve itself. e.g. y = sin(x). This is a 1-d curve, given that there is a single parameter. The y axis on the graph represents output, rather than input.

As an aside to the devs, two nits discovered on Android (Pixel 9) today. 

1) When in a comment thread, clicking the popup "pencil" icon on the lower right creates a brand new thread at the top level, rather than a comment within the currently viewed thread.

2) When writing a comment of any kind, the text view does not move when the text extends into the keyboard space. This means thatthe user constantly has to type blind, and minimize the keyboard to check correctness. There is no way to scroll down while typing.

@John

You've pointed at one of my favorite paradoxes that mathematicians have been aware of since Zeno's time.

Space is 3-dimensional.
Planes are 2-dimensional.
Lines are 1-dimensional.
And points have 0 dimensions.

That means that points are nothing!  And yet space is made up of points and nothing but. But if you add nothing to nothing, you always get nothing, no matter how many times you add them up!  0+0+0+0+.....= 0

So, everything is nothing!

@Pedro
But anything LINEAR is one-dimensional, right?
So the clue works.

Clues are not all-inCLUEsive.  If anything that is one-dimensional is LINEAR, then the clue is correct, I think.

@Wes

There is! It's Fox's U-Bet, a chocolate syrup beloved by my generation, who grew up drinking egg creams. Egg creams are remembered fondly by anyone who grew up in New York. A chocolate soda made with not just any chocolate syrup, but only Fox's, a little milk, and seltzer from the soda fountain or the seltzer bottles that we all got delivered. No egg, no cream. That syrup is still being made today, and is available in certain areas of the country that have a kosher section in the supermarket.

@Times Rita
TIL what an egg cream is! But if there’s no egg or cream, where did it get the name?
@Cherry https://asliceofbrooklyn.com/history-of-the-egg-cream/

@Linda Jo

I like the theory that it comes from the Yiddish "echt" meaning "real", but that still leaves the "cream" part to explain.
One might have said that it was "echt kreemig", implying that it tasted really creamy, even though it doesn't have any cream in it.

It does taste creamy, but it definitely doesn't taste "eggy"!
@Mike This jugged my memory of some of your past puns. They are all very “you” but some of them are getting ewer

@Andrzej -- It's not exactly the connection you were hoping for, but here's a puzzle (pointed out by Jim Horne at XwordInfo) with the same theme, where it's presented with a deeper connection: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/3/2018

@Bill

Yeah, that's what I thought, but I didn't bother to check the etymology.
Ouch, it's a Sunday. I don't really enjoy those huge grids.
@Forrest I love sports! Especially when they kick the home run basket!

@Forrest
It takes a lot of gumption to post a Comment like that.

@Ruu

What?!

@Ruu

Sir, this is Four Seasons Landscaping.

@HeathieJ

It’s in the Mini.

@Emlyn

Your enthusiasm made me smile. Thank you, and congrats! 😃

@Emlyn This was also the first crossword I've managed to do without having to google anything (yes, even the baseball ones!) 
So I totally get your excitement :) Tillykke!

@Emlyn
We might say you are FLUENT in english :))))

@Beverly Johnson

Or even langauge-fluid.

@Beverly Johnson

My English is pretty fluid after a glass of wine or two.
@FJC Eli with an aleph is usually short for אליהו or אליעזר (or sometimes אלימלך), there is an עלי too which does mean high (ספר שמואל א)

@Ruth

Maybe it exists. I think the overwhelming majority of Hebrew speakers would say that the name Eli means “my god” and few or none would say “high” is the meaning of the name.

@FJC

I just checked with my wife who is also a native Israeli and she said it really depends. The way we pronounce Eli in English doesn’t really have an exact equivalent. Her first instinct was to say it meant “high” and the Biblical priest was spelled with an ע so that makes sense, and arguably that’s probably where the name in English was taken from. (I think Jordan’s insistence on the translation below of “ascent” is also correct but too limited). On the other hand, it could also be a nickname of Eliyahu (אליהו) or something similar with an aleph —her fathers name, coincidentally—which certainly means “my God”—and perhaps is a more common name in modern Israel. And of course there is the song transliterated “Eli Eli” (pronounced AY-LEE) which means my God, and it seems like crosswords have used this translation more often in the past. But, all things considered I would say the clue is certainly not incorrect as written.
@LBG Brllant!

@Linda Jo

My wife makes a very good flan. When she does, I always compliment her as an excellent flâneur.

@Jane Wheelaghan
I've never had an ICEE (and I'm not sure what fast-food emporium sells them, come to think of it) but it's sure to be a disappointment if you ever do get one.

@Jane Wheelaghan
I'd not heard of a bhaji before, and you're not likely to find Indian food at a deli. I checked crosses to make sure it was not an onion bialy.
@Mean Old Lady Usually there are found at gas stations, adjacent to the self-serve soda machines.

@Grant

Onion bialy is redundant.

@Grant
Indian food is everywhere! Samosas, pakoras and bahjis. We don't really have delicatessens any more, they seem to have disappeared. I think maybe Indian food is the equivalent of Tex-Mex in the USA. I've had hundred of Indian meals but only maybe 3 fajitas and no tacos or other variations.

(1) The only confusion is thinking that crossword clues and answers must be synonyms or definitions.

(2) An earlier poster explained the difference in detail.

@Barry Ancona
Kindly refrain from discouraging the picking of nits.  One of the joys of the English language is the precision it affords us.

MOL,

When editing copy, the OP's point would not be a nit, it would be a mistake to correct.

When editing puzzles, the point is the mistake.

This is the puzzle, not the copy desk.

@Mean Old Lady,

Discouraging? I always thought he was a contributor! 😁

@Bruce

I know what you mean. When the windshield gasket on the Subaru I had at the time started to become unglued years ago, I could have attempted the complex and expensive job of replacing it, but I just duct taped it back into place. Simple, elegant - perfection.

@Bruce

I’d say usually the simplest solutions tend to be ingenious as well when they are unexpected. My best example is the mathematician Gauss whose teacher (the story goes) asked the kids in elementary school to add up the numbers 1-100 to keep them busy. Gauss realized you could solve this quickly by taking pairs from each end: 1+100=101, 2+99=101, etc. There are 50 such pairs so the answer is 50 x 101 =5,050. There’s a solution that’s elegant, ingenious and simple!

@Bruce
